greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If n is even then 0, otherwise n.
comment: Multiplicative with a(2^e)=0 if e>0 and a(p^e)=p^e for odd primes p. - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 01 2011
A005408 and A000004 interleaved (the usual OEIS policy is not to include sequences like this where alternate terms are zero; this is an exception). - _Omar E. Pol_, Feb 02 2013
Row sums of A057211. - _Omar E. Pol_, Mar 05 2014
Column k=2 of triangle A196020. - _Omar E. Pol_, Aug 07 2015

a(n) is the determinant of the (n+2) X (n+2) circulant matrix with the first row [0,0,1,1,...,1]. This matrix is closely linked with the famous ménage problem (see also comments of Vladimir Shevelev in sequence A000179). Namely it defines the class of permutations p of 1,2,...,n+2 such that p(i)<>i and p(i)<>i+1 for i=1,2,...,n+1, and p(n+2)<>1,n+2. And a(n) is also the difference between the number of even and odd such permutations. - _Dmitry Efimov_, Feb 02 2016
reference: Franz Lemmermeyer, Reciprocity Laws. From Euler to Eisenstein, Springer, 2000, p. 237, eq. (8.5).
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
C. Kravvaritis, Determinant evaluations for binary circulant matrices, Special Matrices, V2(1) (2014), 187-199.
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,2,0,-1).
formula: a(n) = n^k mod 2n, for any k>=2, also for k=n.
a(n) = n * (n mod 2). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Jun 29 2013
a(n) = 2*a(n-2)-a(n-4), for n>4. - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Aug 07 2015

a(n) = Product_{k=1..floor(n/2)}(sin(2*Pi*k/n))^2, for n >= 1 (with the empty product put to 1). Trivial for even n from the factor 0 for k = n/2. For odd n see, e.g., the Lemmermeyer reference, eq. (8.5) on p. 237. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Aug 29 2016
program: (MAGMA) I:=[1,0,3,0]; [n le 4 select I[n] else 2*Self(n-2)-Self(n-4): n in [1..80]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Feb 24 2014
results.author: _José María Grau Ribas_, Jul 24 2011
ext: Formula for a(n) extended by _Wolfdieter Lang_, Dec 21 2011
